Guiding Light (known as The Guiding Light before 1975) is an American television soap opera that is listed in Guinness World Records as the longest-running drama in television in American history, broadcast on [MASK] for 57 years from June 30, 1952 until September 18, 2009, preceded by a 15-year broadcast on radio.

Guiding Light is the longest running soap opera and the fifth longest running program in all of broadcast history; only the American country music radio program Grand Ole Opry (first broadcast in 1925), the BBC religious program The Daily Service (1928), the [MASK] religious program Music and the Spoken Word (1929), and the Norwegian children's radio program Lørdagsbarnetimen (first aired in 1924, cancelled in 2010) have been on the air longer.
On April 1, 2009, it was announced that [MASK] canceled Guiding Light after a 72-year run due to low ratings.
On October 5, 2009, [MASK] replaced Guiding Light with an hour-long revival of Let's Make a Deal, hosted by Wayne Brady.

When 100 Grand made its debut, it had been two years since any quiz show with a five-figure cash prize or higher had aired on any broadcast network (large jackpots were still seen at the time on bowling shows, such as [MASK]'s Jackpot Bowling and ABC's own Make That Spare, both of which regularly offered jackpots over $10,000); it would be over a decade more before six-figure jackpots returned to television game shows.
